THE BEST FPS GAME TO EVER EXIST.
If you want the ORIGINAL FPS and Story telling experience, this is the game for you. Forget Call of Duty, play this instead. Get the whole damn bundle while you're at it.
You will not regret a single action packed moment of this game. This is one of the most profound experiences that a game can have on a person. The characters stick with you, with the player feeling like Gordon Freeman the entire time. The lore of this game is just *Chef's Kiss*
Valve always knows how to make games, and this one especially makes you feel like you want to be in that universe, saving humanity, being puppeteered by GMan who uses you for his own goals, fighting the deadly Combine soldiers and the soldiers who want you dead.
Even being so old, the graphics are really good due to stupendous Art Direction. The scenery, the massacres, the particle effects... they never fail to amaze.
Plus, there are several mods that one can try. 
This game, along with its Episodes, is the most valuable work of art to ever exist during our time.

Single-handedly the best video game series of all time, no cap.

[h1]A masterpiece brimming with details.[/h1] 
[hr][/hr]
My first exposure to this game was on the Xbox Original, believe it or not. Since then, I've replayed this game an innumerable amount of times. After not having played it in years, I decided to buy it again on my steam account, and I'm still just as in love with it, if not more. 

Half-Life 2 is a shooter from 2004. It might seem "simple" or "basic". But even 17 years later, not a lot of games can come close to emulating what it did, or do it in a scale Half-Life 2 does. I'm going to try my best to summarize some of my favourite strong points of this game, but bear in mind that it won't be a full comprehensive list of what this game achieves wonderfully.

I talk about each of these points in further detail with examples in a youtube video:
https://youtu.be/iCHGghgo2eI
Check it out, if you wish, or if you'd rather watch that than read the summary of each point below!

[h1]A Silent Protagonist[/h1]
Half-Life 2 does not have a voiced protagonist, and it's a good thing. A lot of games fall into the trap of having their main character narrate everything in front of their eyes, and doesn't let the player form their own thoughts from the environment. (and there is quite a good bit of environmental story-telling in this game!) So many moments in this game where a voiced protagonist could ruin the fun immensely. A voiced protagonist isn't a bad thing at all, and there are some games that use a voiced protagonist well. But Half-Life 2 benefits greatly from not having one.

[h1]Learning by Experiencing[/h1]
I give detailed examples of this in my video, but I'll try to explain what I mean in text form. This game does not give any tutorials, apart from small blurbs that say "W ,A ,S ,D to walk" or "E to pick up objects". but this game does a wonderful job at teaching you what you are capable of in the game, purely in a "show-don't-tell" method. 

It shows you how an enemy behaves, various ways to deal with enemies, what you can do to the environment, and how you can apply each core mechanic in subsequent puzzles, fights and challenges you face. The game teaches these with zero text pop-ups or boring tutorials, almost purely through the environment, with some sections having a character or two explain to you the basics instead.

[h1]Gorgeous World, Meaningful Details.[/h1]
This game did an amazing job with the details. I've played and replayed this so many times, but even in my most recent playthrough I notice more details I've never noticed before. Details that add to building up a world, too. Interactions among NPCs, Announcer messages, Things on noticeboards, Graffiti on walls... They are all wonderful additions to making this new world you're thrust into so much more believable, and understandable to a newcomer.

Enemy Combine Soldiers even have randomized codenames given to them, consisting of a randomized word, and number. And they actually use their names and one another's names in their radio chatter, when communicating throughout a battle. Even location names in their radio chatter differ in each encounter. This is the type of detail I've never noticed till I've replayed multiple times.

Literally from the moment this game launches, the *main menu* immerses you in a rendered environment, with little things inhabiting it moving around, with beautiful ambient noises. And these environments change based on which chapter you're at in the game, too.

[h1]Characters and Voice Acting[/h1]
This game does a pretty wonderful job at establishing their main characters. For a pretty story-intensive game, there aren't a whole bunch of characters. there are probably only 8 or 9 main characters you find. But I find myself engaged in not only these characters, but the world beyond them, too. The game ties these characters with many events and places of the world, and not too much in a confusing way. Especially if you've played Half-Life 1, it's pretty nice to see so many references and characters tied to the events of that game. (Though, IMO, you don't necessarily need to fully play HL1 to enjoy this game. Maybe just a summary would suffice, if you'd really like.) But despite the small cast of characters, these are characters that add majorly to the world, instead of being characters solely for the purpose of populating the world.

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
This game is an extremely polished game that holds up to this day. It goes on sale for like 75% off every major sale. Just buy it. 

[url=https://youtu.be/iCHGghgo2eI]Here's my video again, if you'd like to see more, including quite a few examples for these points[/url]
(Keep in mind, this is my first time doing an actual review/analysis format. I apologise if the video OR this Steam review is convoluted or not helpful! Have a wonderful timezone ahead, either way <3 Thank you for reading!)

Un clasico.
El cierre de una era y el inicio de otra.
Un FPS con narrativa, jugabilidad, personajes, animacion, y un motor grafico inovador para su tiempo. 
DEBES JUGARLO.

UNICO CONTRA:

-El juego puede presentar bajones muy esporadicos de FPS debido a que es un juego viejo y genera incompatibilidad con nuevas placas de video y drivers. Desactivando la opcion de "multi core" en opciones avanzadas soluciona una parte. GRAN problema por asi decirlo, es en el captulo "Seguid a Freeman", donde inevitablemente en cierto segmento aleatorio se crasheará el juego , obligandonos a comenzarlo de nuevo desde "Nueva partida" para poder continuar con la historia.

Je recommande ce jeu, des cinématiques sont très bien gérées, l'histoire est vraiment bien, l'interface n'est pas très encombrante voir pas du tout dès le début du jeu car elle nous laisse très bien admirer les graphismes et les petits scénarios scriptés.

Dommage que le jeu d'origine n'est pas un multijoueur intégré au lieu de passer par Synergy et que les voix des acteurs ne sont pas formidables mais ne gâchent pas insertion.

J'ai payé ce jeu 8.19€ et je n'y regrette pas même si ce jeu est paru en 2004 j'aime encore refaire complètement la campagne du jeu.

[hr][/hr]
[table]
[tr]
[th][b]MY RATING:[/b][/th]
[th][b] 🌟 🌟 🌟 🌟 🌟 🌟 🌟 🌟 🌟 ✘ [/b][/th]
[th][b]9 / 10[/b][/th]
    [/tr]
[/table]

[b]Anyone who remembers the end of Half-Life knows that hero Gordon Freeman was offered a job by the mysterious G-Man. [/b]

Half-Life 2 doesn't bother to get into this story, but instead hears a short and confusing speech from the tie wearer before waking up on a train unsuspecting. 

[b]What are you doing here? 
How do you get here What about the Xen aliens? [/b]

Most of these questions remain unanswered until the end, the story unfortunately only unfolds in fragments - and especially when you think you have put most of the puzzle pieces together into a reasonably recognizable image, the game is over.

This is not a big problem for the die-hard gamer, but by the end of the game at the latest, the Half-Life newbie will be completely confused, especially since the developers failed to provide at least a summary of the first story or an introduction to the characters. This is all the more regrettable as the game is teeming with innuendos, familiar characters, and inside jokes that only connoisseurs can relate to.

The game doesn't have the best graphics, not the best AI, not the best story, not even necessarily the best sound - [b]but in the end Half-Life 2 is much more than the sum of its parts[/b]. 

The world itself is coherent, everything fits together harmoniously, you really have the feeling that you are shooting your way through a real world. Okay, this feeling comes at the cost of nasty loading times, but it's more than worth it! 

Half-Life 2 is not a boring shootout, but an action-adventure that, despite the strict linearity, gives you a lot of freedom - which means that you don't even consciously perceive this linearity as such. It's one of the few games where you progress as slowly as possible because you fear it might suddenly be over. All in all, including all the counterpoints, Half-Life 2 is a masterpiece, a milestone, a must-have for every PC gamer, whether a shooter friend or not.

[b]As always, those who rely on achievements, they have a lot to do. I had fun and definitely recommend it.[/b]

[hr][/hr]
[b]MY PROS AND CONS:[/b]

✅ quite extensive
✅ neat dialogues
✅ great weapons
✅ good atmosphere

❌ frequent and long loading times
❌ partly jerky animations
❌ Mediocre AI
